timeline.bodyText: why are you changing the mod time, but not the value? The mod time should reflect the value's time, right?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
If the new proposed value is same as old proposed value, then only update the modTime.
Consider when user update topic with value1 at t1, then update with the same value at t2. If another update happens at t3 when t1< t3< t2, then the update will take effect, but this is not the intention
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: Actually I don't know if it's a desired behavior. I'll revert this change for now
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

timeline.bodyText:
I don't really think we should call remove here because that will remove the watchers and send updates that it was removed. But what you really want is to just replace it atomically, not delete and then add.
You might want to create a Topics, copy the watchers over, then directly remove it from the children so that it never fires the WhatHappened.Removed, because that isn't really accurate.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
'copy the watchers over' doesn't work because the subscriber for Topics is ChildChanged and the subscriber for Topic is Subscriber, they have different interface. One is taking Node parameter, another is taking Topic parameter. Topics node also have child nodes, and these child nodes also have watchers. We do want to notify child watchers with 'removed' event.
I also considered creating a new WhatHappened enum value, nodeTypeChanged, and unify the Subscriber and ChildChanged interface. That requires a bigger change though.
Currently, if you call lookupTopics() on a Topic node path (or vice versa), it will throw an illegalArg exception. If you call findTopics() on a Topic node path (or vice versa), it will return null. I guess we need to re-think these to consider how to properly switch a node between Topics and Topic. This is not high priority right now, I can add a TODO here
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: I think I might be happier with the unified subscriber interface so that you don't remove and then add it back. Not sure that we currently have a situation where this matters (I think that we always subscribe to a higher Topics which we know won't change types).
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Some subscribers are taking Topic state. eg: _State topic. I can go through the codebase to check.
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: I tried implementing switching node between container/leaf, find out it's too big a change for this PR. I'll leave it for now and add TODO
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

timeline.message:
Add NodeTypeChanged event type in WhatHappened enum

The event type shows a node is changed and switched between a container node and a
leaf node.

Changed function interface of Subscriber and removed ChildChanged
interface. Subscriber now applies to both Topic and Topics listener.

timeline.bodyText: why do we need these?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: to set parent for a node
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

timeline.bodyText: this shouldn't really be necessary, right? Can we just use lookupTopic which will create the node properly without this manual work?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: lookUpTopic will throw illegalArgException since the node already exist and is not Topic instance
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: Then we could add a method to "override" properly I guess. At least encapsulate this logic.
replies.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: I don't think it's necessary now. So far replaceMap() is the only place where a node type can change
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

replies.bodyText: +1, I would also prefer if it was done through lookupTopic such that we wouldn't need two ways to change nodes
replies.author: shaguptashaikh

replies.bodyText: LookupTopic/LookupTopics doesn't change value of a node, it just creates new nodes (creating new node doesn't fire publishing event). The value is changed through Topic.WithNewerValue(), which notify the subscribers in the publish queue. If we try to implement removing/replacing logic in LookupTopic/LookupTopics, the order of publishing queue can be tricky.
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

timeline.bodyText: this shouldn't be needed since the existing child is going away, right?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Not really, parent node need to remove the child from children and child need to remove reference to parent. Otherwise, when informing the children in the old container node of removal, the 'childRemoved' event will bubble up to root parent.
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

interface. Subscriber now applies to both Topic and Topics listener.

timeline.bodyText:
I see you are approaching this with 4 branches here: leaf -> container, leaf -> leaf, container -> container, and container -> leaf.
So I would suggest move this comment down btw current line 229 and 230. And also add the missing comment for leaf -> leaf and container -> container just to be clear and consistent.
timeline.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: sure
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

timeline.message: split nodeTypeChanged into changedToTopic and changedToTopics

timeline.bodyText: These additional enum values here look redundant to me. I think what you're using these for can be achieved using the existing childChanged event because you fire changedToTopics / changedToTopic event in Topics->replaceMap() only to transform them to WhatHappened.childChanged at Topics.java:364 and Topic.java:151. Other than that these are only used in a test class for assertions, can't we do that without introducing new events? Or am I missing something?
timeline.author: shaguptashaikh

replies.bodyText: I plan to separate out the PR of node type switching.

timeline.bodyText: this warning means that a null dereference is inevitable. Shouldn't it be fixed instead of ignored?

replies.bodyText: Not really. This warning just means there exist a code path that the value is always null. It doesn't check whether you refer to the value in the code path. http://findbugs.sourceforge.net/bugDescriptions.html
